ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: SOOOOO many amazing things, this course really forced me to think about a lot of things differently. For example, coming into this course I detested philosophy--it just frustrated me and I didn't get why it was important. This course really challenged my ways of thinking and taught me so wonderful new things.
I have learned more ways to hone my writing through receiving helpful feedback

I learned how to think critically about readings and to draw connections between readings and units. Most importantly, I learned how important it is to not just consider science as just as an objective field, but as a field with nuance. It is what we, as humans, make it out to be.

I learned about science fiction, narratives and paradigms in science, and different ways that people have told stories about science. I read and watched widely across short stories, novels, plays, academic texts, and films. This was a thoroughly interdisciplinary and inter-media class, so I got practice in analysis and synthesis across genres and media.

I read a variety of texts on the interrelation of science and narrative, including science fiction and the popularization and communication of science. I engaged in interesting conversations on topics such as communication, humanity, and the use and misuse of science. I improved my writing skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great course! I enjoyed the classes and the topics we covered. I really enjoyed the people and the conversations we had.

The readings for the course were all very interesting with a good mix of fiction and nonfiction pieces. Although the format for the final paper was very flexible, I would have liked if it were a paper assignment. Or, just having another paper or two for the course would be great for practicing writing.

The topic of the class is wonderful: it attracted students with all sorts of backgrounds and interests, and the discussions we had in class were better for it. The wide variety of texts was also a strength: I think everyone found something new, something interesting, something challenging in the syllabus throughout the semester. I think the organization of the class could be improved: because it is a wide range of material, it sometimes felt like some weeks didn't connect as well as they could have, while links between other weeks were really strong.

The professors are a lot of fun, and lead some really wonderful conversations. They obviously have put a lot of care into the syllabus and into developing course materials, as the texts that we were asked to read were universally engaging and interesting. Occasionally, we were asked to read an entire book in preparation, which always seemed a little bit too much reading for one week. However, most weeks the readings were interesting and manageable. The writing portion of this class was super manageable - one 5 page paper on a scientific object, one ~6000 word annotated bibliography, and one final 10-12 page research paper. I had a lot of fun completing these assignments.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think given the circumstances, it went quite well!
The ten-minute breaks during our almost two hour long Zoom classes were helpful (staring at a screen for too long makes us numb and not think as well).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend. If youre looking for a writing credit and are a science student, youd enjoy this class!

I would recommend this course if you're actually interested in the intersection between science and the humanities, but maybe not if you are a STEM student just looking for a WR credit. Find another WR class that involves science writing.
Yes! This is a really fun course that engages with a wide variety of topics in science, writing, history, and theory.

I would recommend this course to a student who is interested in the interplay of science and narrative. I already expected to find the materials and the discussions interesting, but I was surprised with how deeply engaged I was and how surprising I found the new ideas that I was exposed to. This is a great writing credit for a STEM student - I was able to primarily write about my courses of study, critically engaging with topics which I already had great interest in. For those who are writing-weary, this course is fairly low-workload.

Definitely! It was great to have weekly discussions about the reading from people who come from very different academic backgrounds. The discussions never disappointed and were always stimulating! (I am a STEM major)

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
